name: Tobias
comment info: The pie charts are visually appealing and simple, but I don’t think they are the best way to compare the students’ answers. Some slices look very similar in size, which makes the differences hard to judge. A bar chart would have made the comparisons clearer. Still, the colours and layout make the chart easy to understand at a glance. The movie revenue chart looks cool because of the posters, but the design actually makes it harder to read the data. The images distract from the bar lengths, so it’s not easy to compare revenues across years. If I were to recreate it in Excel, I’d use a standard bar chart. I do like that the timeline is clear, but overall the chart focuses more on style than clarity.

name: Jessica AOSE
comment info:
The graph depicts fourth-grade students' top concerns about global issues, with homelessness coming in at 42 percent. However, the sample consists primarily of children from urban areas, which raises the possibility of bias. Taking a more diverse sample of 14-year-olds from various geographic locations may alter these findings and produce more accurate results. I'm curious why they were most concerned about the homeless when more pressing issues such as global warming and war created a greater threat to society. I'm also curious how recent this survey was, as global warming and the ongoing current conflict between Israel and Hamas and Russia, and Ukraine could have influenced the results if it had been conducted more recently. This relates to my community because I have 4th grade cousins who live in urban communities and I’m curious if homeless is also on their minds

name: Amelia AOSE
comment info:
These paralleling graphs depict public opinion on major issues in the country and how people are handling those issues. The first graph asks what the major problems are with the answers including homelessness, war, money, climate change, and other. The second graph then elaborates on public sentiment on whether or no the older generations in power are handling these issues well. It can be inferred that the younger generations were the groups surveyed. Homelessness and the housing criss are prominent issues on the minds of Millennials and Gen Z. Similarly, climate change and current international issues are important to many young people and are prominent issues on social media. This inference is then furthered by the majority vote that Adults are not running the world well. It is unlikely for older people to vote against themselves, so it is fair to assume that the poll was held among younger people. This relates to me because I am a member of the younger generations. The results and my relationship to the graph make me wonder how my generation will run the country when it is our time. My generation is passionate and seems to be very discontented, so I am looking forward to seeing how these traits affect the future. 

“Our world, as run by adults”

name: DeAnna McDonald (moderator_
comment info:
Thanks to all who responded.   Here are some of the catchy headlines posted:  “4th Grade Point of View: What’s Wrong With the World?” by Henry of Gull Lake High School in Richland, Mich.; “Little Kids with Big Opinions on Global Issues” by Michael of Mich.; two headlines from Traverse City West Senior High School in Mich. -- “Fourth Graders Take on World Issues. Are They More Aware Than You?” by Natalie and "Children Give Their Opinions On World Problems And How Well We're Doing” by Seth; "Kids Vote: What's Wrong With the World?" by Justin of Masterman School in Philadelphia and two headlines from Perth Amboy High School in N.J. -- "Kids Speak Up On World Problems" by Arturo and “Humanity's Problems: What Are the Kids Saying?” by Emily.
 
Please return on Friday when we will have a summary of the topic, additional questions, shout outs for some of the best headlines for the graph and Stat Nuggets -- definitions of words that relate to the graphs and where you can find them in the graphs.
 
The next graph will be released by Friday, March 15 with live-moderation two weeks later on Wednesday, March 27.  The topic – Africa’s youth.
 
Signing off – Sharon Hessney from Boston, who has many questions she would ask students, such as “Which graph in this feature do you like the most and why?”, and DeAnna McDonald of Univ. of Arizona in Tucson, who was impressed that so many students recognized the difficulty in using these graphs to generalize to a population of all fourth graders.

name: Yachen Huang
comment info:
This graph of what fourth graders think about the biggest issue that needs solving now is an interesting insight into what younger people think about our current situation. I noticed that the first pie chart's answers are related to current events. The most common issue that these fourth graders chose is homelessness. Currently, a lot of big states are being affected by homelessness. Some examples include  California(Skid Row, the Mole people, etc), New York, and many more states. The second most popular choice is war. As one may know, Russia is invading Ukraine. Though most of the attention has died down, it's still a big impact. The second chart asks about whether adults are doing a good job at running the world. Most fourth graders disagreed which I also agree with.

One thing I wonder about is whether these views are from a biased view of a fourth grader. These fourth graders might not fully view the world's current events, which might skew the results.

I feel that our class would have a drastically different answer. I feel that homelessness and war would be pushed down the list while other options would be pushed up. There would also be more of a consensus on whether the current adults are doing a good job at running the world.

One headline that fits this article is: "Fourth Graders - Can They Run A Country?"

replies.comment info:
HI, @Yachen Huang --

You mention bias.  VERY important.  As stated in the two questions above the graphs, these are the opinions of SOME fourth graders.  There is a lot we don't know about this sample and the survey.  What do you wonder about the survey and its results that relate to how bias they are in representing a group larger than those who were interviewed?

replies.comment info:
Good afternoon, @Esther Seiferheld --

Thank you for your very thoughtful response.

I don't think we can say that the statistics are inaccurate.  Unless someone "cooked" the data, they are the responses of "some" fourth graders.  (See the two questions above the graphs.)  Rather than being inaccurate, the sample of unknown size may not be representative of their schools, their cities and, for sure, not the country.  

Is there a categorical question that you would like of students?  Maybe you and your classmates could do a survey, analyze it and present the findings.  In the Reveal that will be posted Friday morning, there are step-by-step instructions on how to do this.  

The Learning Network would appreciate seeing your survey and its results.  Please send them toLN@nytimes.com

comment info: I notice that the responses given are inaccurate but align with what someone would imagine a 4th grader to answer. An example of this is homelessness being voted as the biggest problem that needs to be fixed. While it's not necessarily wrong, other large problems, such as world hunger, were voted what would seem disproportionately low. I think the reason that homelessness was voted so high was because of what the fourth graders experience in their everyday lives. The cities that the students that were interviewed come from, San Diego, Providence, and Spokane, are all cities with very high rates of homelessness. While it may be somewhat easy for a family to hide money problems or violence on the news from a kid, it's hard to hide homelessness. You can't just throw an invisibility cloak over people sleeping on stoops when you walk down the street. It is often hard for fourth graders to imagine other people's problems who live very different lives, so it may be hard for them to imagine war or the extreme hunger and lack of resources some people have to live with. name: Liam Maier
comment info:
Viewing the graph, I think it’s strange that 42% of these fourth graders think homelessness is the most serious issue in the present day. With so many other important issues on the world’s canvas, it’s interesting that nearly half decided on this. Similarly, 30% said war, rather than issues that could cause the entire world to face problems- such as climate change and world hunger. I definitely don’t oppose the two issues that the kids are so drawn to, but it’s definitely not what many adults and even teens would say. In the current world situation, I know that many Gen-Zers strongly oppose climate change, which I believe would hold the largest portion of the chart if they were the subjects.
        Additionally, I notice that a great portion of the students think adults are doing a poor job of running the world. It’s interesting that such young people have seemingly already opposed leaders of the world. That brings me to ask the question- Have adults taught them this? At the age they’re at, not many have access to news websites or social media, so all their knowledge of world leaders presumably comes from others. It’s quite strange!
	If it was up to me and my classmates, we’d surely have similar opinions about world leaders, but that comes from our knowledge of the world. However, I believe we’d definitely gravitate towards climate change rather than war and homelessness, as the kids voted.

name: Emma AOSE
comment info:
These two pie charts show 2 questions asked to four 4th-grade classrooms in Spokane Washington, Louisville Kentucky, Rhode Island, and San Diego California by the NYT.  The questions asked to these 4th graders were: the biggest problem that needs solving right now and do you agree or disagree with this statement that adults are doing a good job running the world? I noticed that the first question for the biggest problem that needs to be solved right now is that homelessness was the highest percentage at 42% and after that, the issue of war was rated at 31%. I noticed in the second pie chart that the kids disagreed that adults are doing a good job running the world at 40%. The kids were interviewed in large cities and said the major problem is homelessness makes sense because California is known to have a large homelessness problem. I wonder if the NYT interviewed kids in different smaller or more rural cities would homelessness be seen as a big problem in the world right now? Maybe a 4th-grader who lives in a more rural state would say that money or climate change is more important due to the large agricultural economy in that state. This relates to me and my community because I have traveled the country and have spent time in major cities that have a homelessness problem and have seen no change to fix the problem in these cities. 

Through the Eyes of a Fourth Grader

replies.comment info:
HI, @Emma AOSE --

Yes, we can wonder about who was surveyed and why.  Note the questions above the graphs.  All we can say about these results is that they describe "some"  fourth graders.  We do not know if the sample of students was representative of fourth graders.  Therefore, the results may be biased.

name: Katherine H
comment info:
These two pie charts show how various groups of fourth graders across the US felt when asked political questions. The first question asked, “What is the biggest problem that needs solving right now?” showed a majority of fourth graders responded with either homelessness (42%) or war (31%). Other responses included climate change (17%) and money (4%). The second question “Do you agree or disagree: adults are doing a good job of running the world.” 40% of fourth-graders responded that they disagreed with the statement, 30% responded they agreed, and 30% responded they did not know. 

Students who were interviewed lived in places such as San Diego, Providence, and Spokane. All these cities have a huge homelessness problem. This makes sense as to why so many students voted homelessness as the biggest problem that needs solving. If the NYT interviewers had targeted other cities in the US, I wonder how these stats would change. Would the majority of fourth-graders still feel homelessness is the biggest issue needing to be addressed? In my community, homelessness is not a glaringly obvious issue. With a large portion of my community more concerned with green energy alternatives, I believe that the fourth-graders I am from may vote more that climate change is the biggest problem that needs to be addressed. Overall, I think getting input from children could be beneficial in looking into solving issues

“Are You Smarter Than A Fourth Grader? Kids Take On Burning Political Questions”

replies.name: D
replies.comment info:
@Katherine H 
Hello there Katherine.
You have hit upon an important point with respect to using a sample to summarize a population.  I noticed in the subtitle the phrase "what do some fourth graders think...." this verbiage is a subtle nod to your point that the cities in which these fourth graders live are not representative of all fourth graders.

But an important question of mine is how the wording of the question influences the overall results.  Is there a clue in the graph itself as to whether the "biggest problem" question was open-ended or provided the students with a list of choices?  If the latter, do you think that the order of the choices might have made a difference?

name: Avery K AOSE
comment info:
From the data, I noticed that the fourth graders polled voted homelessness as the biggest problem in the world at 42%. This was followed by war at 31%, and climate change at 17%. I find it interesting that the children voted climate change and war as larger issues in the world, because these problems could impact their generation the most as they grow up and become adults. The fourth graders also disagreed with the sentiment that adults are doing a good job of running the world. This makes me think that the children polled are fairly knowledgeable about world problems. I would have assumed that children would list bullying as a big world problem because that is something that is more likely to be addressed at that age. I also would have thought more children would think that adults were doing a good job in running the world by looking up to and relying on their own parents. I agree mostly with the children’s response to the biggest problems in the world that need to be solved. “Should 4th-Graders Run the World?”

name: Kevin
comment info:
1) At first glance, I found it interesting that 42% of surveyed fourth graders perceived homelessness as the greatest threat and that 40% of surveyed fourth graders don’t believe the world is being run well by adults. Although homelessness is a disastrous problem that has to be dealt with, as a high schooler, I perceived war and climate change as much more alarming threats. This made me wonder why would a fourth grader be more concerned about homelessness than violence and worldwide disasters. I hypothesize that homelessness is a much easier threat to perceive. Whenever a fourth grader is out with his parents, he is unlikely to see war or the real-time effects of climate change. These are far away problems only heard of on TV, unlike homelessness, which he could see on the corner by his street. A fourth grader's concern over homelessness may add to the statistic that 40% of fourth graders do not find the world being run well.
Continuing my observation, I began to wonder how the survey was taken. If you look at the graphs, the survey was done on fourth graders in Spokane, Louisville, Providence, and San Diego which are all big cities. Homelessness is often most prevalent in big cities, where rent is higher and where there’s a greater concentration of people. If the survey was taken in rural America or deeper into the Suburbs, I wonder how the survey would change.

comment info: As many older siblings and parents know, 4th graders are normally pretty sincere and honest about the things that they talk about. This can be seen in the data pulled from the graph. This outlook on life comes from kids who normally lead simple easy lives without a lot of complications, so when they think something is a problem, it is a major problem. Most of them also believed that the adults were not leading the world properly. If we have a younger generation telling us that we have problems then we should work to change those things. They notice what we can’t and because of this they sometimes are more aware and wary of the problems that they see. The problems that they notice in the world are some of the same problems that my friends and I notice in the world around us. In surrounding areas where I live, there are large  populations of homeless people and it  is not uncommon to find many of them camping along the roadside. Being  near the ocean also allows us to notice the effects of climate change as  the summers have become hotter and the winters colder than they have ever been. In the past two years alone there  have been hail storms that haven’t happened previously for an incredibly long time. All in all, I think that it is a smart decision to listen to and support the thoughts of these fourth graders.

I wonder why there are such split opinions on if adults are doing a good job of running the world, and if these are fourth graders from urban environments with larger homeless populations. These results definitely defer due to the sizeable information gap that separates elementary students and high school students. My headline is "A 4th grader's infatuation with homelessness"

replies.name: m
replies.comment info:
@Yafet Andualem 
I agree with what you are saying, if a student lives in a city then they are more exposed to homeless people rather than students who live in a small town. this makes me wonder if they included small town students in the questioning, and how much the numbers would change if they were questioning high schooler's or middle schooler's.

name: Zlata Rudenko

replies.name: D

name: Addy and Luke
comment info:
We notice that the majority of children do not trust their government or at least feel uneasy about their actions. 

We wonder why most kids believe that the biggest problem in the U.S is currently the homeless? Is that what is being preached in schools the most? 

When we were that age we might of agreed with these kids that our biggest issues in our world were homeless and war too. 

Should we promote the 4th graders to the white house?

name: Abigail M
comment info:
I noticed that 40% of fourth graders think adults are doing a bad job of running the world.  I think this is because they don't yet have a concept of politics, or because they are able to recognize the need for change.
    I wonder how much of this is a result of information from what their parents may have told them since many young kids lack a sense of independent thinking. Many small kids listen to & repeat what their parents say, so I am curious to know if that is the case.
    When I was a 4th grader, I'm not sure I would have had a formulated opinion on these things quite yet either, but that might not be the case for all of them.
    If I were to name this graph, I would name it, "Should 4th graders run this country instead?"

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Abigail M --

You have a great understanding of why the opinion of fourth graders on adults running the world is the way it is.  

What would be a more meaningful way to survey individuals about how the world is being run?  Who would you ask?  What would your question be?  How would you carry out the survey?

name: Tyler Zook, Caleb Patterson
comment info:
We notice that a majority of people disagree that adults are doing a good job running the world, although not by a great majority. Less than half. A problem that they haven't seemed to fix is homelessness. the neglect to solve this might have contributed to the increase of the homeless.

We wonder if adults putting more focus on fixing money instead of other solvable issues like homelessness. If adults agree they are doing a good job running the world, what issues do they consider?

This relates to our community because the population of Denver has grown vastly and so has the homeless problem, increasing 58% since 2016. There are efforts to fix it but it seems like it hasn't changed that much. We are not adults so we are unsure of what adults could be doing to participate in making communal problems better.

Headline: "Do You Have Issues? Yeah, Me Too."

name: Louis Wozniak
comment info:
I notice that homelessness take up almost half of the graph. This is very interesting to me because the surveyed classrooms are for the most part, in higher populated cities. This most likely exposed the 4th graders to homelessness, and less of the other topics. However, bullying is also a factor in schools, but showed less of a response to be chosen. I think the statement is fairly accurate, as most 4th graders arent extremley knowledgable, and each three categories are pretty even.

I wonder if the questions were influenced by any teacher giving the poll. This would lead to different results displated. I also wonder how students would solve the problems they chose. It would be interesting to see the perspective of the younger generation, especially since the majority disagree with how adults are running the world.

The results differ from me, as I probably would have a different response for each category. Also, I live in a less populated, more rural town, and homelessness is very slight, if not nonexistent in the community. I think this would change the answers.

The Youngsters: How do they see the world?

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Louis Wozniak --

You’ve hit on so many of the issues with these graphs.  I wonder about more issues with the survey.  How many students were surveyed in each school?  How were they picked?  When were they surveyed and were they surveyed at about the same time?  How was  the question asked about the problems – open-ended, a list or some other way.

On Friday, we will reveal more information that relates to the graphs.  (None of it answers the above questions.)  There, you will find steps on how to conduct a simple survey with categories.  Perform your own survey and analyze the results.  What do you notice?  What do you wonder?  We at the Learning Network welcome seeing your survey and your analysis.

name: Mia
comment info:

Conundrums in small eyes.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Mia --

Seems like you are looking for more depth in the responses from the fourth graders.  What questions could you ask in the survey to get that depth?  You may want to answer this question for older students, too, since you can ask them so much more.

name: Zac Leach
comment info:
1. What do you notice?
It's interesting to see how these fourth graders see the world. It makes sense to me on how they see homelessness as the major thing needing to be fixed since that's what they see in their own community. It's right in front of them

2. What do you wonder?
I am interested in how 30% of the students said that they don't know if the adults are doing a good job running the world. It's a hard question for sure, but I wonder if that wasn't an option, would it swing more negative or positive to the question.

3. How do the results shown in the graph differ from your opinion and that of your classmates?
We see all of these as problems but war, murder, assault, and others of the sort, are ranked higher on our list than homelessness. To be fair, kids don't know much about that kind of stuff due to it be so graphic and that's good. We want our kids to slowly learn about the vileness of the world, not at once. If they found out about all the Earth's problems, they wouldn't be able to hold on to any hope. The hope of one day growing up and making a change.

4. Create a catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea.
The Future Generation: What's wrong with the world right now

name: Taylor Belz
comment info:
I notice that the fourth graders believe homelessness, war, and climate change are the biggest problems. I am surprised that they knew enough about these topics to know they are a problem. I was also surprised that only 30% of fourth graders believe adults are good at running the world. Maybe they didn't take the poll seriously, but these fourth graders seem much more observant than most people would believe. 

I wonder what type of education/new exposure these kids are open to, and how much it influenced their position. I wonder how the fourth graders determine whether something is more/less important than something else. I wonder how these fourth-grade answers would compare to those of a first-grader, a high school student, and the average adult.

Me and many people in my class would agree with the fourth graders, that adults are not doing a great job at running the world. Maybe we are biased because we are not adults, or maybe we blame the adults in charge for all the bad things that happen. Personally, I don't think all adults do a bad job, but I think we could be doing much better. I would agree that homelessness and war are top issues and that climate change is a major up-and-coming problem. I would show more concern for the economy and weapons (at least in America), as well as mental health issues in younger generations. 

Catchy Headline -->
A Look Inside a Fourth Grader's Mind: What's Wrong In Their World?

name: A. VanHuysen
comment info:
What do you notice?
-All of the analyzed areas are in cities, potentially leading to inherent bias. 
-The terms for the issues are simplified, probably to “gear” the graph for kids. 
-Over-generalizations are prevalent, probably influencing the results of the graph. 


What do you wonder?
-How do the kids' ideas of the issues relate to that of adults? 
-What is being taught in schools that lead to this conclusion (ie CNN10, Scholastic News?) 
-Does their location (in larger cities) lead them to give different answers than students in rural schools would? 
 
How do the results shown in the graphs differ from your opinion and that of your classmates?
-My belief is that the biggest issue of our day is international diplomacy- or therefore lack of. It ties in directly to war, but the war itself is not the issue. Our incompetent politicians who cater their policies to win votes instead of peace is the issue. As a world, we need to work to improve cooperation, and the people speaking for us on major issues. 


Create a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea
	When I Grow Up I Want to Fix the World

name: Morgan AOSE
comment info:
I notice that most fourth graders think that homelessness (42%) and war (31%) are the biggest problems that need solving. I also notice that climate change (17%) and money (4%) are far less prevalent. Many fourth graders disagree (40%) that adults are running the world well.

I wonder why so many fourth graders think homelessness is the biggest issue facing the world. Perhaps it is because they see unhoused people on the street, which presents a more obvious issue than climate change. I also wonder why war is considered the second biggest problem-- it would be helpful to know when the data was collected (ex. when the Russo-Ukrainian War or Israel–Hamas war began). I wonder how the internet has changed fourth graders' perceptions. Perhaps the news has caused them to believe adults are doing a poor job.

I think that climate change, war, and world hunger are the biggest problems that need solving. My classmates think homelessness is the largest issue, displacing climate change in importance. This relates to me and my community because young people will soon be able to vote and have their voices addressed. When today's youth "run" the world, my hope is that more people will agree that adults are doing a good job of it. I think that adults are doing a fine job, but need to lessen their polarization.

"Elementary Insights: Our Youngests' Biggest Problems"

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Morgan AOSE ---

What perceptive insights into the graphs. 

I wonder how the selection of the schools and the classrooms within the schools have affected the survey.  Very possible that the students are not representative of U.S. fourth graders.  

If you go to the National Alliance to End Homelessness “State of Homelessness:  2023 Edition,” you can see the homelessness population and per capita by state and by county.  See what the homeless situation is in the states where the fourth graders live.
